dialog: Hello Medi, what is Hepatitis A?
Hepatitis A is a viral infection that is spread through contaminated water or food. It can cause liver damage if left untreated.
How is it different from other types of hepatitis?
Unlike hepatitis B and C, Hepatitis A does not cause chronic liver disease and usually goes away on its own within a few weeks to months.
What are the symptoms of Hepatitis A?
Symptoms of Hepatitis A can include fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice.
Is there a vaccine for Hepatitis A?
Yes, there is a vaccine for Hepatitis A. It is recommended for all children, travelers to certain countries, and people at high risk for the disease.
Who is at high risk for Hepatitis A?

dialog: Hello Medi, I recently had Hepatitis A and recovered. What lifestyle changes should I make to prevent getting it again?
If you have recovered from Hepatitis A, you are now immune to the virus and should not get it again. However, you can still take steps to prevent the spread of the virus to others.
What steps should I take?
You should be sure to wash your hands thoroughly after using the bathroom and before preparing food. You should also avoid close contact with others if you have symptoms of illness.
Is there anything I should avoid eating?
You should avoid raw or undercooked shellfish, which can be a source of the Hepatitis A virus.
What about alcohol?
You should also avoid alcohol, which can be damaging to your liver.
